questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerA: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When students board a school bus, the driver should:
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, the driver should supervise the loading while watching all mirrors for any students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: If a bus stalls on a railroad track, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Evacuate the bus and get everyone far away from the tracks.
questions.answerB: Keep everyone inside the bus and try to wave the train down to make it stop.
questions.answerC: Keep everyone inside the bus and wait for help.
questions.answerD: Keep everyone inside the bus and call a tow truck.
questions.explanation: If a school bus becomes stalled or trapped on railroad tracks, the driver should immediately evacuate everyone from the bus. To best avoid flying debris from the bus being struck by a train, the students should be led far away from the bus at an angle that is in the direction of any oncoming train.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: Where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door across from the driver
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror of a school bus should be mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the vehicle. It should be used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Point to or touch each item.
questions.answerC: Explain what you are checking and why.
questions.explanation: As a part of earning your CDL, you will have to pass an inspection test and demonstrate that your vehicle is safe for operation. During the vehicle inspection test, you will have to walk around the vehicle and point to or touch each item and explain to the examiner what you are checking and why. You will not have to crawl under the hood or under the vehicle.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: When checking the springs during a vehicle inspection, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Ensure torsion springs are not damaged.
questions.explanation: When checking the springs as part of the vehicle inspection test, you should look for missing, shifted, cracked, or broken leaf springs, as well as broken or distorted coil springs. If the vehicle is equipped with torsion bars, torque arms, or other types of suspension components, ensure that they are not damaged and are mounted securely.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop your own route to show off your driving skills.
questions.answerB: Listen to directions from the examiner.
questions.answerC: Bring a passenger to ride with you.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must listen to and follow the directions given by the examiner. They will never ask you to drive in an unsafe manner.

questions.question: A passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerB: Does not have any control devices.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that do not display any traffic control devices are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: ABS allows a driver to:
questions.answerB: Maintain control of their vehicle while braking.
questions.answerC: See farther ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle when braking on a slippery surface.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should stop to pick up students who are walking to a designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents may choose where the bus stops are located.
questions.explanation: School bus drivers may only pick up students at official stops designated by authorized school officials.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to result in the most student deaths per year?
questions.answerA: Students loading and unloading a school bus
questions.answerD: Accidents in which drivers ignore traffic signals or signs
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year while getting on or off school buses than while riding as passengers on board school buses.

questions.question: To safely unload a bus, students should:
questions.answerA: Remain seated until they are told to exit.
questions.answerB: Stand up and head toward the door while the bus is slowing down.
questions.answerC: Exit the bus and stand directly next to the bus while it is being driven away from the stop.
questions.explanation: Students who are about to unload a school bus should remain seated until the driver tells them that it is safe to exit. After exiting the bus, they should walk to a position that is at least 10 feet away from the bus so the driver can clearly see them.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep your wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: An inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: Inspect the outside of the bus.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus. It should be adjusted to show every student on the bus, including the students directly behind the driver.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: When asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror of a school bus is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.answerD: See in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: During the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: A pull-up always counts against the applicant.
questions.answerB: A pull-up should be completed at least once.
questions.answerC: Stopping without changing direction is not considered a pull-up.
questions.answerD: Excessive pull-ups are acceptable in the opinions of some test administrators.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, a pull-up will be scored any time an applicant stops and pulls forward to gain a better position. Stopping without changing direction will not. An excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The pedal surface has been smoothed out.
questions.answerD: There is something underneath the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: As a general rule, where should students be kept during an emergency?
questions.answerB: On the side of the road near the bus
questions.answerC: In a field away from the bus
questions.explanation: In most emergency or crisis situations, students on a school bus will be safer and more easily controlled if they are kept on the bus than if they are evacuated. However, if staying on a bus will expose the students to risk or injury, the bus driver should escort them to a safe location.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to result in the most student deaths per year?
questions.answerA: Students loading and unloading a school bus
questions.answerD: Accidents in which drivers ignore traffic signals or signs
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year while getting on or off school buses than while riding as passengers on board school buses.

questions.question: When should you inspect the mirrors on a bus?
questions.answerD: Is not necessary to inspect the mirrors.
questions.explanation: The mirrors of a bus should always be inspected before a trip. Adjust them as necessary before beginning to drive.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: When taking the basic control skills test, drivers are:
questions.answerA: Not permitted to stop and exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerB: Encouraged not to exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerC: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in reverse.
questions.answerD: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in neutral and the parking brake is set.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, you must place the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake before exiting the vehicle to check its position. You may check the position of the vehicle no more than twice, except during the straight line backing exercise, where you may look no more than once.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: If exiting a bus, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Never make contact with the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: The vehicle crossing over an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerB: A driver executing a single pull-up.
questions.answerC: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerD: The vehicle stalling while the driver shifts gears.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: If students on the bus cause a disturbance while other students are unloading, what should you do?
questions.answerA: Immediately walk to the back of the bus and take care of the disturbance while students unload.
questions.answerB: Wait until the students are done unloading and then take care of the disturbance.
questions.answerC: Have a student who is closer to the disturbance handle the situation while you supervise unloading.
questions.explanation: The process of loading or unloading students from a school bus requires a driver's full concentration. If there is a behavioral issue on the bus, wait until the exiting students are safely off the bus and out of the way before you address the problem on the bus.

questions.question: Who must provide emergency response information?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide emergency response information to drivers.

questions.question: Who is responsible for installing placards on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: While shippers of hazardous materials are responsible for providing necessary placards, it is the driver's responsibility to actually place them on the vehicle.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: When you are behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package:
questions.answerB: Has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: Was packed at a specific location.
questions.answerD: Will be placed on the trailer first.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they are certifying that the package has been prepared in accordance with its applicable rules.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the items can be distinguished by:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials being listed first.
questions.answerB: The non-hazardous materials being written in pencil.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials being listed in red ink.
questions.answerD: The hazardous materials being written larger than the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: If the letter “G” appears in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper, the shipping paper must also include:
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: A "G" in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper indicates that the description in Column 2 is the generic name for a material. A generic shipping name must be accompanied by a technical name.

questions.question: A driver must take the HazMat knowledge test:
questions.explanation: You must take and pass the written English version of the HazMat knowledge test and be cleared through a federal background check before every renewal of your CDL.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, the driver:
questions.answerA: Can cross railroad tracks without slowing or stopping.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching railroad tracks, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at railroad crossings before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Should never drive over railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials must always be stopped before being driven over railroad tracks, even if the tanks are empty.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle transporting hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: Someone other than the driver should do it.
questions.explanation: Always turn the engine off before refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials. Someone must always be at the nozzle controlling the fuel flow.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load hazardous materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: Always set the parking brake before loading or unloading hazardous materials.When loading or unloading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use hooks, or any other tools that could damage containers or packaging. Hazardous materials should be kept away from heat sources.

questions.question: The National Response Center must be notified of an incident resulting in any of the following, except:
questions.explanation: The National Response Center must be notified of any incident that results in death; hospitalization; $50,000 or more in estimated property damage; an evacuation of the general public or closure of a major transportation route/facility for more then one hour; fire, breakage, spillage, or suspected contamination involving radiation, bacteria, or toxins. Additionally, if the carrier judges the situation to be so serious that it should be reported, it should be reported.

questions.question: What does a material’s hazard class reflect?
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will fall into one of nine hazard classes. The material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is by:
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: How do you label a hazardous material if the proper label will not fit on the material's package?
questions.answerA: The label may be placed on a tag securely attached to the package.
questions.answerB: A scannable QR code may instead be attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The HazMat label should be reduced in size to fit on the package.
questions.answerD: The label may be pasted to the wall of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit on a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in the trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to a corrosive material must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation surrounds the package and will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be transported in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Brace containers so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation. All hazardous materials packages must be secured.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: In general, before loading or unloading any flammable liquids, an engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: If a box contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials packages with containers of liquid inside must have orientation markings with arrows pointing in the direction that should be upright.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials become more dangerous when exposed to heat. Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded away from heat sources.

questions.question: Shipping papers:
questions.answerA: Are not needed for most shipments.
questions.answerC: Should be stored in a special compartment in the cab.
questions.answerD: Can be kept as a digital file.
questions.explanation: For all shipments of hazardous materials, the shipper must use shipping papers to inform drivers and dockworkers of the risks presented by the cargo.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: If cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.answerD: Spray the leaking containers with water.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: Identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guidebook.
questions.explanation: The United States Department of Transportation (DOT)’s Emergency Response Guidebook (ERG) lists all hazardous chemicals and their assigned identification numbers.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: If loading corrosive materials, you should not:
questions.explanation: Containers of corrosive materials should be kept in their correct upright positions. They should not be dropped or rolled.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should be used only by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply any necessary placards.

questions.question: Unless a package is clearly unsafe, what does the driver need to accept a package of hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: Unless a package is clearly unsafe or does not comply with the Hazardous Materials Regulations, you may accept the shipper's certification that it was properly packaged.

questions.question: What should a carrier do if hazardous materials are not properly prepared?
questions.answerC: Accept the shipment, but make a notation on the paperwork
questions.explanation: It is the responsibility of a carrier to refuse improper shipments of hazardous materials.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: What is used to warn people about hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped warning signs, called "placards," are placed on the outside of a vehicle carrying hazardous materials to serve as a warning.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult for the driver to see behind the trailer.
questions.answerB: There may be extra weight in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Trailers are not made to be driven in reverse.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything that is behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse if it is absolutely necessary.

questions.question: When backing up while coupling a trailer, the tractor should be positioned:
questions.answerA: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: On a leaf spring:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: While inspecting coupling equipment before a trip, the air lines should not:
questions.answerA: Be connected to the glad hands.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the convertor dolly, ensure that all components are present and in proper working condition. Be sure to check the upper and lower fifth wheel, the air lines, and the electric lines. The air lines should be securely attached to the proper glad hands and should not contain any leaks. They should be attached with enough slack to allow easy turning.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, what is the best way to make your vehicle more visible?
questions.explanation: In conditions of poor visibility (such as at dawn, at dusk, in rain, or in snow), you should turn on your low beam headlights to make your vehicle easier to see. Do not use your high beams when driving near other vehicles.

questions.question: When checking your tires, which of the following is not an issue to correct?
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerD: Tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch on the front tires
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting tires include: air pressure that is too low or too high; using radial and bias-ply tires together; tread depth of less than 4/32 of an inch in major grooves on front tires; and tread depth of less than 2/32 of an inch on all other tires.

questions.question: A fire extinguisher is a required piece of safety equipment.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should check for required emergency equipment, including at least one fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If you see lights ahead while driving in fog:
questions.answerA: You can assume the lights are on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.answerD: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles use the ____ method when changing gears.
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with unsynchronized manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: Extremely hot temperatures can cause:
questions.explanation: Because air expands when hot, tire pressure increases as temperatures increase. This can sometimes result in tire failure. Consistently check your tire pressure when making a trip in hot weather.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down extra quickly.
questions.explanation: Air expands as it gets warmer, so the air pressure in your tires could reach dangerously high levels while being used in very hot weather. If this happens, stop and let your tires cool. Do not let air out of the tires, as this could result in the pressure dropping to an unsafe level once the tires cool down.

questions.question: In a set of triples, the shut-off valves at the rear of the middle trailer should be:
questions.explanation: When operating a double or triple, the shut-off valves at the rear of the last trailer should be closed. All other shut-off valves should be open.

questions.question: If you press the tractor air supply control and your trailer's spring brakes do not release, you should:
questions.answerC: Turn the engine off and on again.
questions.explanation: It is important that all of a vehicle's equipment is in proper working condition before beginning a trip. If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push in the tractor air supply control, you should make sure the air line connections are properly attached and sealed.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: It is important to inspect your tires before every drive. Rust around wheel nuts may indicate that they are loose.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: Most heavy trucks with manual transmissions require ____ to change gears.
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to shift gears. Learning to effectively change gears by double clutching takes practice.

questions.question: Older trailers are not equipped with spring brakes. This means that if the air supply for a vehicle's air braking system leaks away:
questions.answerB: The trailer will not have brakes.
questions.explanation: Older trailers do not have spring brakes. This means that if the air supply in an older trailer's air tank has leaked away, there will be no working brakes connected to the trailer and its wheels will turn freely.

questions.question: When coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Only couple one set of glad hands.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand loose.
questions.explanation: When coupling air brake hoses, you should make sure the proper pairs of gland hands are connected. They are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Shaded areas of a road:
questions.answerB: Are usually blocked from all moisture, so they cannot freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice has melted on other areas of the road.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight and warm up more slowly, shaded areas will remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: When stopping in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer your trailer to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Veer your trailer to the left and stop.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line but will still allow you to turn if necessary.

questions.question: Noting the speed of other vehicles is one way to determine when to upshift.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: If you are driving in fog, you should not:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, be sure to slow down. Turn on your flashers and low beam headlights.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a vehicle’s air brake system?
questions.explanation: Components of an air brake system include an air compressor, an air compressor governor, air storage tanks, air tank drains, an alcohol evaporator, a safety valve, a brake pedal, foundation brakes, supply pressure gauges, an application pressure gauge, a low air pressure warning signal, a stop light switch, a front brake limiting valve (on some older vehicles), spring brakes, and parking brake controls.

questions.question: Doubles and triples:
questions.answerA: Turn easily due to their centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Are more difficult to turn than smaller commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Due to their size, doubles and triples cannot be turned suddenly. They require extra care to avoid rollovers when turning.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: Coupling can be tested by a driver:
questions.answerA: Placing their fingers inside the coupling mechanism.
questions.answerB: Pulling against the pin of the second semi-trailer.
questions.answerC: Placing glue over the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Releasing the orange lever in the cab.
questions.explanation: It is essential to safety that a driver inspects coupling before starting a trip. Trailer coupling on a double or triple combination can be tested by pulling against the pin of the second semi-trailer.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerD: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Brakes out of adjustment will:
questions.answerB: Cause some of the brakes to overwork and malfunction.
questions.explanation: Brakes out of adjustment will fade before those that are properly adjusted. Brake adjustment must be checked frequently to help prevent brake issues.

questions.question: Doubles combinations:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to jackknife than singles.
questions.answerB: Are less likely to roll over than singles.
questions.answerC: Require a larger reaction time than singles.
questions.explanation: Because doubles and triples are more vulnerable than singles to jackknifing and rolling over, drivers should look far ahead of their vehicles so they can react to hazards well in advance and slow down or change lanes gradually.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter air tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from air tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks are equipped with drains that allow water and compressor oil to be removed from the system. If allowed to build up, water and compressor oil can damage an air brake system.

questions.question: If a spill occurs from a tank vehicle you are operating:
questions.answerA: You may have to pay for clean-up efforts.
questions.answerB: You will be exempt from clean-up costs if the tank was loaded by another person or company.
questions.answerC: You will be required to notify the local conservation department.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to transport liquids or gases in a leaking tank. If you do drive a leaking tank, you may be liable for the costs of cleaning up the spilled material.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as fire extinguishers, are:
questions.answerA: Only needed in vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Required in all commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles must carry appropriate emergency equipment, including fire extinguishers.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle transporting hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: Someone other than the driver should do it.
questions.explanation: Always turn the engine off before refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials. Someone must always be at the nozzle controlling the fuel flow.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill:
questions.answerD: You will slow to a stop.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is traveling on a downward slope, the force of gravity will cause its speed to increase.

questions.question: When loading liquid cargo, you should take into account:
questions.answerC: The air pressure in the tires.
questions.answerD: The speed limits on the route.
questions.explanation: Factors that affect how much liquid is safe to load into your tank include how much the liquid will expand in transit, the weight of the liquid, and legal weight limits.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly, before other vehicles can enter into the lane.
questions.answerB: Move slowly in case another vehicle is in the lane.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If there is a vehicle in the other lane that you did not see before beginning to move, they will have more time to react to your vehicle.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: To prevent your tires and engine from overheating while you are driving in especially hot weather, you should:
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the hotter your engine and tires will become. When it is very hot, you can help prevent this overheating by decreasing your speed.

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: Tread depth in the major grooves on a front tire should be at least:
questions.explanation: Tires need to have at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on other tires.

questions.question: When traveling through a work zone, you should:
questions.answerC: Steer with one hand and keep the other hand free.
questions.explanation: Always observe posted speed limits for work zones. Slow down if road or weather conditions are adverse, and slow down even more if workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerC: A tractor that travels faster than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as "bobtail tractors." Bobtail tractors are difficult to operate and drivers must exercise caution.

questions.question: One way to prevent hydroplaning on wet road surfaces is to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving on a wet road surface, the risk of hydroplaning is increased if your tire pressure is too low or your tire tread is too worn. If you begin to hydroplane, release the accelerator and push in the clutch to slow down.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerC: There is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerD: Vehicles are too close to one another.
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver changing lanes or turning too quickly.

questions.question: A flare is required emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should check for required safety equipment. This includes warning devices for parked vehicles, fuses, and liquid burning flares.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. With ABS equipped on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same manner that you would without it.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After starting the engine, warning lights and buzzers should go out right away. If a light stays on, it usually indicates an issue with the vehicle.

questions.question: How soon after starting a trip must cargo securement be checked?
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Exercise will help a person sober up after drinking.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, tricks like exercising or taking a cold shower will not speed up this process. The only way to become sober after drinking is to allow the body the time it needs to get rid of the alcohol.

questions.question: Skids happen when:
questions.answerA: Tires lose their grip on the road.
questions.answerB: There is too much weight in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Skids happen when tires' traction with the road surface decreases. This can be caused by over-braking, over-accelerating, over-steering, and driving too fast.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, the engine oil pressure should come up to normal:
questions.explanation: After a vehicle's engine is started, the engine's oil pressure should rise to its normal level within seconds. Do not drive a vehicle with oil pressure that is too low.

questions.question: Carrying liquids in a leaking tank:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable if it is only for a short distance.
questions.answerC: Is not dangerous if it is raining.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable if you are running behind schedule.
questions.explanation: When inspecting any style of tank, the most important thing for a driver to check for is leaks. Transporting any type of gas or liquid in a leaking tank is illegal.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread depth of 2/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: A surge occurs with which type of cargo?
questions.explanation: Tank vehicles carrying liquid cargo are vulnerable to surge. Liquid surge is an occurrence in which a wave of liquid sloshes from one end or side of a tank to the other, causing dangerous effects on handling.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, your minimum following distance should be:
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. When traveling at higher speeds, follow the same formula, then add one additional second to your following distance.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in a higher gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Not both be in contact with the road surface.
questions.answerC: Be different sizes from one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: Baffled tanks:
questions.answerA: Should be inspected by an electrician.
questions.answerB: Allow liquid cargo to flow through the tank.
questions.answerC: Control the temperature of the liquid cargo.
questions.explanation: Baffled tanks are divided by bulkheads with holes in them. These bulkheads inhibit front-to-back surge while still allowing liquid to flow through the whole tank.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: Baffled tanks:
questions.answerA: Are damaged and should not be used.
questions.answerB: Control liquid surge while still allowing liquids to flow through the tank.
questions.explanation: Baffled tanks contain holed bulkheads that allow liquid to flow through the tank. This helps to inhibit front-to-back surge, but does not prevent side-to-side surge.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If someone is tailgating you, it is a good idea to open up the space ahead of your vehicle to make it easier for the driver to pass you. Increasing your speed is not a good idea because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: Shaded areas of a road:
questions.answerB: Are usually blocked from all moisture, so they cannot freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice has melted on other areas of the road.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight and warm up more slowly, shaded areas will remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: Before beginning to drive downhill, you should:
questions.answerA: Take your vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: To avoid overusing your brakes, you should always shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is best to allow more room to open up in front of your vehicle. This will help you avoid the need for sudden stops, which could result in the tailgater rear-ending you, and will make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up may only make things more dangerous by prompting the other driver to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume all emergency exits work properly.
questions.answerD: Not waste time looking at the handrails and floor lining.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Make sure all signaling devices, such as bathroom emergency buzzers, work properly.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed down gradually.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be pushed down quickly.
questions.answerC: The brake pedal should be pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.answerD: The amount of force required on the brake pedal will be the same each time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Press the brake pedal down smoothly and gradually every time you slow or stop. The amount of brake pressure you need to apply depends on the speed of your vehicle and how quickly you need to stop.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: If you doubt that you have enough space to safely drive under a bridge or sign, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not certain that your vehicle will fit under overhead objects, you should slow down and take a different route, if possible.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection:
questions.answerB: Is helpful in identifying minor issues before they become major problems.
questions.answerC: Should not be done by the driver.
questions.answerD: Should be performed once a month.
questions.explanation: A vehicle should be inspected before every trip to help ensure that any small mechanical issues are caught before they become more serious problems. It is better to discover a problem with your vehicle before a drive than after the drive has begun.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop and take a break ____ to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of becoming fatigued on a long trip, a driver should stop for a break at least once every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: When backing, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the passenger’s side mirror.
questions.answerC: Turn toward the passenger’s side whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should back up slowly and use the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle. Use a helper to monitor your blind spots whenever possible. You and the helper should agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: Federal and state laws require:
questions.answerA: Drivers to regularly inspect their vehicles.
questions.answerB: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they believe there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Drivers to inspect their vehicles if planning to travel out-of-state.
questions.answerD: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they will be transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Commercial drivers are required by federal and state laws to inspect their vehicles before every trip. Regular inspections can help drivers identify issues before they become dangerous and costly.

questions.question: Once passengers have boarded your bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Begin driving as soon as the door is closed.
questions.answerB: Warn them before you begin to drive.
questions.answerC: Allow the passengers time to sit or brace themselves before you begin to drive.
questions.answerD: Begin driving as quickly as possible.
